Getting Started

Complete the following, and email your results to Mr. Gabriner at gabrinerd@mail.weston.org.
Please use YourID #1 as the Subject of your message.
Label subsequent assignments similarly, just change the assignment number.
Email your work when it is complete and ready to be graded.
  1. Read all parts of the Getting Started document, and complete the lab in Activity #5.
  2. Carefully read Section 1 of the textbook, which you can find at
    www.htdp.org/2003-09-26/Book/curriculum-Z-H-4.html.

Strongly recommended but not required:
Download DrScheme for your home computer.

Data Types


In this — and all subsequent function definitions — you must include a contract, a purpose statement, and at least one test case.

Do Exercises 2.3.1 through 2.3.3.
Do Exercise 2.4.2.

Branching

  1. Develop a function called can-vote? that consumes a person’s age and produces a boolean that tells you whether the person is old enough to vote.

  2. Write a program that consumes a number representing a student’s percentage score on a test and produces a string representing an appropriate comment for that student. For example, (teachercomment 72) might produce "should try harder".

  3. Use symbols for the days of the week.
    Write a function is-weekday? that consumes a day of the week symbol and produces a boolean that tells you whether or not the day is a weekday.

  4. Write a program begins-with-vowel? that consumes a string and produces a boolean that tells you whether or not the word begins with a vowel.

Be the Computer


Here is some practice for the quizzes that require pencil and paper and no computer.
Read the instructions at the top of the page and take their suggestion of writing down your answers before checking them.
Do these on paper or in your head. BE the computer.

At this point in the course you should be able to do exercises A-J.

Looping - Recursion


  1. Write a program called pig that translates a word (in the form of a string) into Pig Latin. Use the simplest dialect of Pig Latin, in which you move an initial consonant (if any) to the end and add "ay" (so "string" becomes "tringsay" and "easy" becomes "easyay"). You may want to use the begins-with-vowel? program that we developed in class.

  2. Write a program called pig! that translates a word (in the form of a string) into Pig Latin. Use the dialect of Pig Latin in which you add "way" to a word that begins with a vowel (so "easy" becomes "easyway"), otherwise you move any initial consonants to the end and add "ay" (so "string" becomes "ingstray").

  3. Challenging: Write a function piggy that correctly handles the cases where y is a vowel as in the word myth . It must also handle the case where y is a consonant as in the word year.

  4. Very Challenging: correctly handle words with no vowels such as tsk or cwm.

Compound Data Types


  1. Read Section 6.3 and Section 6.4 of the textbook (Structure Definitions and Data Definitions).

  2. Carefully read the Commentary on Structures.

  3. Exercise 6.3.3.

  4. Exercise 6.4.1 (Part 4 only).

  5. Define your own version of a student structure and create three appropriate examples of students.

  6. HtDP Problem Set, Section 6, #2, 3.

  7. Carefully read Section 6.5 of the textbook (Designing Functions for Compound Data).

  8. Exercises 6.5.1 (Part 4 only) and 6.5.2.

Images


  1. Read the documentation for the image.ss teachpack and the image functions in the world.ss teachpack. You can find the documentation in the help desk.
    You will need to install world.ss for the following exercises.
    On the language menu select Add Teachpack ...
    world.ss can be found in the htdp folder.

  2. Use overlay to draw some simple compound images, such as a blue triangle in front of a green rectangle and vice versa. For example:
    (overlay (circle 100 'solid "red")
         (rectangle 100 150 'solid "blue"))
    You may also want to overlay your own images on top of ones that you download.

  3. Create an American flag.
    The nw:rectangle function may be useful for this one.

  4. Come up with an image made up of circles, rectangles and lines. After drawing it on graph paper draw it with DrScheme. Get approval from me before programming your image.

  5. Challenge: Create the following function:
    ;american-flag
    ;contract: num -> image
    ; purpose: consumes a width and returns a well proportioned american flag of that width.
    see Wikipedia for the correct proportions.

Data Structures


Read chapter 9 on lists and then do the following:
  1. 9.1.2

  2. 9.1.4

  3. 9.3.1

  4. 9.3.3

  5. Make a template for processing a list of numbers.

  6. Use the template to define a function that consumes a list of numbers and returns the sum of the numbers in the list.

  7. Use the template to define a function that consumes a list of numbers and returns whether or not a given number is in the list.

  8. Challenging: Use the template to define a function that increments each number on the list by a given amount and returns the updated list.

  9. More Challenging: Use the template to define a function that consumes a non-empty list of numbers and returns the largest number. (Hint: think about how the recursion should end, it's not the empty list.)

Design & Complexity


  1. HtDP Problem Set, Section 3, #1. Note that there are three teaspoons in a tablespoon.

  2. HtDP Problem Set, Section 3, #3.

  3. Challenging: HtDP Problem Set, Section 4, #5.

Animation


Read the documentation for world.ss.
Pay special attention to the functions for creating scenes and the event handlers.

Download the world.scm and modify it to do the following:
  1. Make the ball move.
    Hints:
    • Write the body of move-ball.
      Add dx to x and dy to y.
    • Modify the key-press function to accept the arrow keys as input.
      When an arrow is hit change the value of dx or dy as appropriate.
  2. Add the ability to change the color of the ball.
  3. Add collision detection and make the ball bounce off the walls
  4. Add the effect of gravity.
  5. Optional: Add a mouse event handler and drag or throw the ball.

Assignment


Use begin and set-structname-fieldname! to modify your world.ss progam. Notice that functions now need to know less information. Changes to structures will not cause a ripple of changes through all your code. Important: Modify a copy of assignment#10. Do not start over and do not lose your working copy of assignment#10

Performance Issues


Write a recursive function that given a number(count) returns a list of that many fibonacci numbers. You will find that the list is in descending order but I want the list in ascending order. Write a function that given a list returns a list in reverse order. Note: do not use the built in reverse function provided by Scheme. Write your own!! If your functions have "ugly" interfaces then write "wrapper" functions that provide a clean interface to the user.

Project


Your first design document will now be due. I want a copy of your write-up and a list of your data defintions. The data definitions should include struct names and the fields in each struct (including the data type of each field).

Note: Start keeping an organized folder or binder of your design documents. This will be handed in as part of your game project.

Complete the Logic Intro, handed out in class. If you're using the handout and forgot to make the correction in class, please be sure to correct the Chain Rule: the conclusion should be "p → r", not "q → r". (The online version is correct already.) A couple of students asked for reminders of the examples I used in class to make sense of the rules of inference, since I did those orally rather than in writing. Here are a few, from Disjunctive Inference on down:

If "p" means "you have cake for dessert" and "q" means "you have ice cream for dessert," then we have...
Disjunctive Inference
This says that if you know that you had cake or ice cream, but then you realize that you didn’t have cake, you can conclude that you had ice cream.

DeMorgan’s Laws
The first one says that if you can’t have two desserts — both cake and ice cream — you can conclude that either you didn’t have cake or you didn’t have ice cream. The second one says that if the waiter tells you that the restaurant is out of both — that is, you can’t have either cake or ice cream — you can conclude that you can’t have cake and you can’t have ice cream.

Simplification
This says that if you tell me that you had cake and ice cream, I can conclude that you had cake. (Alternatively, of course, that you had ice cream.)

Conjunction
This is the reverse: if you tell me that you had cake, and later you tell me that you had ice cream, I can conclude that you had cake and ice cream.

    1 2

  6. q(x) = – (x + 2)2
  7. h(x) = 3(x + 2)2 – 2

In class, and on the last assignment, you analyzed a set of wrapping functions for a square path.

Now sketch graphs for a diamond-shape path, where the guards walk straight from each of the following points to the next, eventually returning to the starting point and wrapping around the diamond again and again: (3, 0); (0, 4); (–3, 0); (0, –4). In this case the function that produces the x-coordinate is called diamx, the one that produces the y-coordinate is called diamy, and the one that produces the rotation angle with its vertex at the origin is called diamang.

Finally, sketch three similar graphs for a circular path, where the guards walk around a circle centered at the origin, starting at (1, 0). In this case the function that produces the x-coordinate is called xc, the one that produces the y-coordinate is called ys, and the one that produces the rotation angle with its vertex at the origin is called rad.

Study for the test. You may use one side of a 3"-by-5" notecard that you have prepared in your own handwriting. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning calculator. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. You will not be given extra time unless you have a legal right to it because of an IEP or a 504; in those cases you must begin and end the test on the same day. You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:
  1. Simplify algebraic expressions, including the correct use of combining like terms, the distributive property, and squaring.
  2. Translate expressions and functions from Scheme to algebraic notation and vice versa.
  3. Given one representation (algebraic rule or formula, table, graph, function machines), represent a function in the other three.
  4. Find values of simple and composite functions for various inputs.
  5. From the graphing form of a quadratic function, identify the directions in which the parent parabola y=x2 has been moved or stretched, and by how much.
  6. Do the same for the graph of a function that is new to you.
  7. Distinguish linear from quadratic and other functions by their graphs (lines vs. parabolas vs. other), their tables (constant vs. second-difference growth), and their algebraic rules (presence or absence of x2 or higher term).
  8. Identify the domain and range of a function.
  9. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

Carefully read Regressions and Scatter Plots on TI-83/84 Calculators, but ignore the last sentence on p. 8 (the one that says you are not required to use the coefficient of determination, R2). The author doesn’t require it in his college course, but we do require it at Weston High School. Along with reading it, follow along with every step on your calculator. You will need to learn all these steps in order to be able to follow them with minimal notes (whatever you write in your lab notebook, plus whatever you can cram onto your notecard for a test).

Study for the test. You may use one side of a 3"-by-5" notecard that you have prepared in your own handwriting. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning calculator. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. You will not be given extra time unless you have a legal right to it because of an IEP or a 504; in those cases you must begin and end the test on the same day. You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:
  1. Complete the square to write a quadratic function in graphing (vertex) form.
  2. Factor a quadratic to write it in factored form.
  3. Solve quadratic equations by the zero product property (if in factored form), backtracking (if in graphing form), factoring (if in standard form), and the quadratic formula (also if in standard form).
  4. Find the inverse of a quadratic or linear function.
  5. Simplify algebraic expressions, including the correct use of combining like terms, the distributive property, and squaring.
  6. Translate expressions from Scheme to algebraic notation and vice versa.
  7. Given one representation (algebraic rule or formula, table, graph, function machines), represent a function in the other three.
  8. Find values of simple and composite functions for various inputs.
  9. From the graphing form of a quadratic function, identify the directions in which the prototype parabola y = x2 has been moved or stretched, and by how much, as well as the vertex.
  10. Find x- and y-intercepts of a quadratic function.
  11. Distinguish linear from quadratic functions by their graphs (lines vs. parabolas) and their algebraic rules (presence or absence of x2 term).
  12. Identify the domain and range of a function.
  13. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly.
Complete Still More Trig Equations. Consult the answers and hints as needed.

Begin studying for your quiz on Nov. 5/6 (CLT, Ch 18, t-dist, confidence intervals).

Find x- and y-intercepts of a quadratic function. 11. Distinguish linear from quadratic functions by their graphs (lines vs. parabolas) and their algebraic rules (presence or absence of x2 term). 12. Identify the domain and range of a function. 13. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

Consider the following data for the winning score (in inches) over the course of many years for three events in the Olympics: men’s long jump, men’s high jump, and men’s discus. The “year” listed is actually “years since 1900.”

  1. Enter the data into your calculator, using four different lists, such as L1, L2, L3, and L4.

  2. How do you interpret year –4, when the description says “years since 1900”?

  3. Using only the long jump data, find the best-fit linear model, the best-fit quadratic model, and the coefficients of determination for both. Which model is the better fit, and why?

  4. Do the same for the high jump data.

  5. Do the same for the discus data.

  6. Using your best equation for each event, predict the winning score in each event for the year 2008.

  7. Now look up the actual winning scores for 2008. You will probably find them into meters, so you will have to convert them to inches!

  8. Finally, figure out how good the predictions were, by calculating the ratio between the predicted value and the observed value for each event.

On the Counting Triangles worksheet, you discovered that a polygon with n sides can always be divided into exactly n - 2 triangles. NEW FACT: Since the interior angles of a triangle add up to 180 degrees, the interior angles of an n-sided polygon always add up to 180(n - 2) degrees. For this assignment, use this new fact to answer #s 1-4 from pp 309-310 of your textbook.

Suppose you need $34,000 to buy that new sports car you have been looking at, but you only have $42.12. You can find a bank that is willing to offer you an annual rate of 4.5% interest on your investment. How long will you have to wait until you can buy the car if: a) The interest is compounded every 4 years. b) The interest is compounded every year. c) The interest is compounded quarterly. d) The interest is compounded continuously. Show your work!

From now on, you need to state all domain restrictions in any trig simplification or identity proof, even when the book does not require it.
  • Lesson 10–1, p. 374, Written Exercises, #42.
  • Lesson 10–2, p. 378, Written Exercises, #17, 28.
  • Lesson 10–3, p. 384, Written Exercises, #15 [do this one quickly and efficiently: do not find the functions of π/12 !], 31, 32.
Here is a list of trig identities that you need to know and/or be able to derive. You may use all of them in your proofs.

Also, you may find it helpful to gain more experience through additional practice in trigonmetric simplifications and identities. The Mathematics for Calculus book that I mentioned in class has 182 simplification problems and identity proofs within its pages! Feel free to come see me to get some of these for practice. Here are a few identity proofs to get you started (as an optional assignment):
  1. tan y/csc y = sec y – cos y
  2. (1 – sin x) / (1 + sin x) = (sec x – tan x)2
  3. cos θ / (1 – sin θ) = sec θ + tan θ
  4. (1 – cos 2x) / sin 2x = tan x

You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:
  1. Tell whether a function is linear, exponential, quadratic, power, or none of these.
  2. Apply exponential functions as models of real-world phenomena.
  3. Find the common ratio (growth factor) from exponential data.
  4. Apply the properties of exponents and logarithms.
  5. Represent functions as algebraic rules (formulas), tables, graphs, Scheme, and function machines.
  6. Distinguish exponential from power equations, and solve both.
  7. Represent translated exponential functions as their graphs and vice versa.
  8. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly.
As preparation, you should go over all your recent quizzes and homework, your Test #3, Building with Logs, and Logarithmic Functions, Part Five, which you worked on in class on Thursday.

These questions concern the version of Newton’s method that was shown in class:
  1. In finding the square root of a positive number, what happens when the seed is negative? Can you prove that this conclusion is always correct?

  2. Adapt the algorithm so that you are finding the cube root of a number. Try out your version by finding the cube roots of 8, 9, and –8, using several seeds, both positive and negative. Do you always find the real cube root? Or do you sometimes find a non-real complex root? Does it depend on the seed?

Test 3 is today. Below is a list of topics you are responsible for:

1. Graphing vectors
2. Graphing polar coordinates
3. Plotting complex numbers
4. Converting between polar and rectangular form, and expressing coordinates in exact value when possible
5. Finding all solutions to quadratic equations
6. Simplifying powers of i
7. Evaluating negative square roots

Please fill out this anonymous course survey and help me to make the course better in the future.
Ch 24 #32 Ch 17 # 12-show a mathematical expression for each part, not just a final answer.

Through experimentation, come up with a good conjecture for this question: Which of the two square roots and which of the three cube roots are found by Newton’s method when applied to a complex number? To be able to compare consistently, try the two square roots of 13–12i (which are 2–3i and –2+3i) and the three cube roots of 8 (which we worked on in class). Keep in mind the original conjecture that it depended on the quadrant of the seed. This turned out not to be quite correct — but it was correct enough in lots of cases that we want to modify it rather than throwing it out altogether.

1. Be sure that the following definitions are in your notebook:
    When iterating any particular function...
    • The Filled-in Julia Set or (preferably) Filled Julia Set (FJS) for that function is the set of all prisoners.
    • The Julia Set for that function is the edge of the FJS. These are a subset of the prisoners, namely those that can become escapees with the slightest change; their orbit is chaotic.
  2. Complete Exploring Julia Sets I (begun in class).

Complete The Logistic Map, at least through #13. You will need to know the definitions of attracting and repelling fixed points before doing this. There are good definitions at www.jcu.edu/math/Vignettes/orbits.htm:
A fixed point may be an attracting fixed point, meaning that the orbits of nearby points converge — are attracted to — the fixed point; or it may be a repelling fixed point, meaning that the orbits of nearby points move away from the fixed point. Other fixed points may be neither attracting nor repelling. For f(x) = x2, 0 is an attracting fixed point while 1 is a repelling fixed point. (Calculate the orbits of x = .999 and x = 1.001 to convince yourself.)

Study for your quiz. You are allowed to bring one 3"x5" and a calculator. You are responsible for the following:
1. identify the degree and leading term of a polynomial.
2. identify the # of turns a polynomial will have.
3. describe the end behavior, using infinity notation.
4. differentiate between polynomials and functions that are not polynomials.
5. write an equation of a polynomial given the graph.
6. locate global/local extrema.
7. sketch the graph of a polynomial using the x-intercepts, the y-intercept, effect of repeated zeros (u-shape, chair-shape), sign of the leading term, and knowledge of end behavior based on an even/odd degree polynomial.
8. convert polynomials to/from standard/factored form.
9. be able to explain all of this clearly and in your own words.

Decipher it!

NWKJT WQCFP QVDQZ MIBZJ LNW

1. Read How Bits and Bytes Works (through the Binary math section).

  2. Read The Binary System. Answer the embedded questions before checking your answers (no need to submit the answers).

  3. Answer the following questions and email the answers to me.

    1. Many people referred to the year 2000 as Y2K, or Year 2K. That’s on the theory that K stands for 1000, which it doesn’t. What year will really be Y2K?
    2. Investigate the y2k38 problem. Do you think this will be a real problem? Why?
    3. Convert the binary numeral 11100101 to decimal.
    4. Convert the decimal numeral 107 to binary.
    5. What is the easiest way to multiply by 4 in binary?
    6. Add 10100011 to 11000010 in binary without converting to decimal and back again.
    7. In the previous question, your answer should have been more than 8 bits long. If your computer couldn’t handle numbers larger than 8 bits, only the rightmost 8 bits would be kept. What would your answer to the previous question be in this case? Figure out how far off it would be by subtracting the computed result from the true result and converting to decimal.
    8. Convert -7 to two's complement form
    9. Use two's complement form to subtract 7 from 12

In prep for MCAS on May 17th and May 18th - look over this website and click on any year from 2009 and back. On the next page scroll down to "Grade 10" and select "Mathematics" to access sample questions along with the answer key.

1. Carefully read the first two parts of “How Email Works”: Introduction to How Email Works and The POP3 Server. Answer the following questions:

    1. What is the difference between a POP3 server and an SMTP server? How are they similar?
    2. Give two examples of commands that are understood by SMTP servers.
    3. Who was Ray Tomlinson, and what he is known for?
    4. What are email headers, and what are they used for?
    5. Give two examples of email clients.
    6. What role does DNS play in the transmission and receipt of email?
    7. What are uuencode and uudecode, and how are they used in transmitting and receiving email?

  2. Learn about color codes by exploring the following:

    • HTML Colors in W3 Schools (including the two follow-up lessons on color values and color names)
    • The Hex Hub
    • HTML Goodies

    Look for patterns relating the codes to the colors!

  3. Suppose you have some random color, like #E066FF. How would you make it redder? greener? bluer? yellower? slightly darker? much darker? slightly lighter? much lighter? Be specific, but only focus on the relevant octets! (In other words, write something like “change the FF to a slightly smaller number, like DD,” or “replace the first two octets with much larger numbers, such as FFEE.”)

  4. Without looking at a color chart, figure out what these colors would look like: #FF1111, #DDDDDD, #333333, and #00DDDD. Then check your answers, and revise them if necessary. Finally, figure out how you could give pretty good answers to this sort of question without looking them up or checking them.

  5. Check out the Jargon File. (If the firewall is blocking you, try the Framed Version and use the upper-left frame to navigate.) At the very minimum, read Part I Chapter 1 (Hacker Slang and Hacker Culture), and look up the meanings of the following useful terms in the glossary in Part II: bang, bogosity, copyleft, cruft, dark-side hacker, flame, Infinite-Monkey Theorem, kluge, LISP, security through obscurity, smoot, thinko. Find a word or phrase with an interesting definition that’s new to you — either on this list or elsewhere in the Jargon File — and explain what’s interesting about the word or phrase and its definition.

  6. Read the Wikipedia article on Web 2.0 and write a paragraph describing ways in which you have personally used Web 2.0, preferably not in the context of this course. (If you missed the Web 2.0 video in class, or just need to see it again, it’s at http://youtube.com/watch?v=6gmP4nk0EOE.)

We will have a test today on factoring and some combinatorics.
Some of you have asked for more practice questions. Here are a few more:
1) Factor 8x^6-27y^6
2) A full house is made up of 3 cards of one kind and two cards of another kind (ex:2,2,2,K,K). How many different ways can a hand of five cards be dealt so that it makes a full house?
3) A lincense plate in a certain state consists of three letters followed by three numbers. a)If repeats are allowed, how many different plates are possible? b) If no numbers or letters can be repeated on a plate, how many different plates are possible?
4) Powerball rules state that they "draw five white balls out of a drum with 59 balls and one red ball out of a drum with 39 red balls. The jackpot is won by matching all five white balls in any order and the red Powerball." If you wanted to be assured to win by playing all possibilities, how many tickets would you need to buy?
5) Mr. McLaughlin is breaking his class of 24 students into groups of 4. Each group will be assigned to a different project. a)How many ways can this be done? b)How many ways can this be done if Meiji and Alexandra need to be in the same group?
Answers (not in order, so do the problems first!): 24C4*20C4*16C4*12C4*8C4*4C4 26*26*26*10*10*10 59C5*39C1 (2x^2-3y^2)(4x^4+6x^2y^2+9y^4) 26P3*10P3 13P2 * 4P3*4P2 (Pick the two suits first) 6*22C2*20C4*16C4*12C4*8C4*4C4

The exam will include numerical problems (2-D, 3-D) and proofs (2-D only) involving the following:
  1. Angles, lines, line segments, & planes (complements/supplements, parallels, perpendiculars, midpoints, etc.)
  2. Congruent triangles (SAS, SSS, ASA, AAS, HL, CPCTC)
  3. Triangle properties (medians, altitudes, concurrencies at various “centers”, Angle Bisector Theorem)
  4. Equidistance Theorem and Midline Theorem
  5. Quadrilaterals (including the hierarchy)
  6. Polygons and polyhedra (including isosceles triangles, angles & diagonals in regular polygons, and Platonic solids)
  7. Similar figures and proportions (including similar right triangles)
  8. Pythagorean Theorem & special right triangles
  9. Right-triangle trigonometry
  10. Equations of lines and circles, midpoints, slopes, intersections, distance
  11. Circles (radii, chords, arcs, angles, tangents, power of the point, sectors, circular segments)
  12. Area, perimeter, and volume (including surface area and scale factors)

Optional 2-Point Reflection on the Spiral Project (written as an individual, not as a group!):
  • Usually in our math class you know that there is an answer to the problem you are trying to solve, and you know that it's possible (at least in theory) for you to find that answer. But there were portions of this project where you didn’t know how to find an answer. Sometimes it wasn’t clear that answers even exist! Describe the advantages and disadvantages of working on open-ended research questions vs more concrete solvable problems.
  • What part of the project did you find the most interesting? Why?
  • What went right during the project? What went wrong?
  • Describe what each member of your group contributed to the process and the product. How did you help?

As requested, here are some solutions. I tried to get them up quickly so someone double check my work: 1) 6P5 2) 30P6 3)5!5! 4)9!-1 (or 9!-2 if a reverse order counts) 5) assuming that the novels and textbooks are all the same a) 6!/(3!2!) b) 4*3C2*1C1 c) 6 (just list them!) 6) 52C13 7) a) 4! b) 2P2*2P2 8) (5C2)(6C2)(4C3) 9)2*7*2*6! (the second two is because for each of the seven places Fand E can be seated there are two ways each of those 7 spots can be filled FE or EF) 10) 20C2 11) 5C2*4C3*5!

Regular expressions are a powerful tool.

The final exam will begin promptly at 8:50 AM on Tuesday, 6/15. Extended-time students will be in Room 8, everyone else in Room 32. You will be allowed to use two 3"-by-5" notecards on the exam; we recommend writing notes on one unit per notecard side, since we’ve studied four units:
  • Quadratics
  • Exponents & Logs
  • Systems
  • Crypto
You will be well-prepared for the exam if you can do the following:
  1. Identify whether a function is linear, exponential, or quadratic, given an English description, a table, or an equation.

  2. Represent a linear, exponential, or quadratic function as a description, a table, and a graph, given any one of these.

  3. Simplify algebraic expressions, including the correct use of combining like terms, the distributive property, and squaring.

  4. Convert quadratic functions from factored form or vertex (graphing) form to general (standard) form.

  5. Complete the square in order to convert a quadratic function from standard form to graphing form.

  6. Given one representation (algebraic rule or formula, table, graph, function machines), represent a quadratic function in the other three.

  7. From the graphing form of a quadratic function, identify the directions in which the prototype parabola y=x2 has been moved, and by how much.

  8. Distinguish linear, exponential, and quadratic functions by their graphs, their algebraic rules, and their tables.

  9. Distinguish exponential from power functions.

  10. Given two points (either on a graph or in a table), construct a linear and/or an exponential function passing through those points.

  11. Given an input and a function, find the output for that input.

  12. Recognize characteristic graphs of exponential and quadratic functions.

  13. Convert equations from exponential to logarithmic form and vice versa.

  14. Evaluate logarithms to any given base, using your calculator where necessary.

  15. Interpret logarithmic functions as the inverses of the corresponding exponential functions.

  16. Use logarithms to solve exponential equations and roots (or fractional exponents) to solve power equations.

  17. Use the properties of exponents to simplify expressions.

  18. Apply exponents and logarithms by constructing and using exponential models to describe read-world situations.

  19. Solve a linear equation in one variable.

  20. Graph a linear or exponential equation in two variables.

  21. Solve word problems involving systems of equations by the method of your choice.

  22. Solve a system of equations in two variables by graphing, and determine whether the equations are independent, dependent, or inconsistent.

  23. Solve a system of equations in two variables by substitution, elimination, or matrices.

  24. Find sum, difference, product, and inverse of matrices. Identify when those are nonexistent or undefined (and explain why).

  25. Solve equations in which the solutions represent matrices or variables within matrices.

  26. Graph linear inequalities.

  27. Graph systems of linear inequalities, and use the results to solve and interpret linear programming problems.

  28. Use the mod operation correctly.

  29. Encipher and decipher with affine, matrix, and RSA ciphers. (You will not need to do the exact RSA calculations as part of the exam — they were done outside of class in RSA Part Four — but you do need to be able to follow the steps in the process.)

  30. Determine and apply congruence classes for various moduli.

  31. Determine good and bad affine and matrix ciphers.

  32. Understand what reciprocals (multiplicative inverses) are, and apply them to the solution of congruences.

  33. Show your work and explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

Branching

  1. Develop a function called can-vote? that consumes a person’s age and produces a boolean that tells you whether the person is old enough to vote.

  2. Write a program that consumes a number representing a student’s percentage score on a test and produces a string representing an appropriate comment for that student. For example, (teachercomment 72) might produce "should try harder".

  3. Use symbols for the days of the week.
    Write a function is-weekday? that consumes a day of the week symbol and produces a boolean that tells you whether or not the day is a weekday.

  4. Write a program begins-with-vowel? that consumes a string and produces a boolean that tells you whether or not the word begins with a vowel.

At this point in the course you should be able to do exercises A-J.

Looping - Recursion


  1. Write a program called pig that translates a word (in the form of a string) into Pig Latin. Use the simplest dialect of Pig Latin, in which you move an initial consonant (if any) to the end and add "ay" (so "string" becomes "tringsay" and "easy" becomes "easyay"). You may want to use the begins-with-vowel? program that we developed in class.

  2. Write a program called pig! that translates a word (in the form of a string) into Pig Latin. Use the dialect of Pig Latin in which you add "way" to a word that begins with a vowel (so "easy" becomes "easyway"), otherwise you move any initial consonants to the end and add "ay" (so "string" becomes "ingstray").

  3. Challenging: Write a function piggy that correctly handles the cases where y is a vowel as in the word myth . It must also handle the case where y is a consonant as in the word year.

  4. Very Challenging: correctly handle words with no vowels such as tsk or cwm.

You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:
1. Simplify algebraic expressions, including the correct use of combining like terms, the distributive property, and squaring.
2. Given one representation (algebraic rule or formula, table, graph, function machines), represent a function in the other three.
3. Find values of simple and composite functions for various inputs.
4. From the graphing form of a quadratic function, identify the directions in which the parent parabola y=x2 has been moved, and by how much.
5. Do the same for the graph of a function that is new to you. Ex: think of the function y=wow(x) on your review sheet.
6. Distinguish linear from quadratic and other functions by their graphs (lines vs. parabolas vs. other), their tables (constant vs. second-difference growth), and their algebraic rules (presence or absence of x2 or higher term).
7. Identify the domain and range of a function.
8. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly - Good luck!!

In class, and on the last assignment, you analyzed a set of wrapping functions for a square path.

Now sketch graphs for a diamond-shape path, where the guards walk straight from each of the following points to the next, eventually returning to the starting point and wrapping around the diamond again and again: (3, 0); (0, 4); (–3, 0); (0, –4). In this case the function that produces the x-coordinate is called diamx, the one that produces the y-coordinate is called diamy, and the one that produces the rotation angle with its vertex at the origin is called diamang.

Finally, sketch three similar graphs for a circular path, where the guards walk around a circle centered at the origin, starting at (1, 0). In this case the function that produces the x-coordinate is called xc, the one that produces the y-coordinate is called ys, and the one that produces the rotation angle with its vertex at the origin is called rad.

You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:
  1. Simplify algebraic expressions, including the correct use of combining like terms, the distributive property, and squaring.
  2. Given one representation (algebraic rule or formula, table, graph, function machines), represent a function in the other three.
  3. Find values of simple and composite functions for various inputs.
  4. From the graphing form of a quadratic function, identify the directions in which the parent parabola y=x2 has been moved, and by how much.
  5. Do the same for the graph of a function that is new to you.
  6. Distinguish linear from quadratic and other functions by their graphs (lines vs. parabolas vs. other), their tables (constant vs. second-difference growth), and their algebraic rules (presence or absence of x2 or higher term).
  7. Identify the domain and range of a function.
  8. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

  3. Look back at your test, and identify each of these statements as True or False:
    1. I learned the definitions in the textbook.
    2. I set up the equations correctly for problem #2.
    3. I knew how to solve the equations in problem #2 and was able to apply my knowledge.
    4. I knew how to solve the equations in problem #2 but made mistakes in doing so.
    5. I understood the symbols used in problem #3.
    6. I knew what the Triangle Inequality says.
    7. I knew how to apply the Triangle Inequality.
    8. I can solve 12-hour clock problems.
    9. I knew how to solve 12-hour clock problems but was not able to apply the principles to a 24-hour clock.
    10. In problem #6, I was able to solve the quadratic equation by factoring.
    11. In problem #6, I was able to solve the quadratic equation by the Quadratic Formula.
    12. In problem #7, I knew all the Rules of Inference and was able to apply them.
    13. I knew all the Rules of Inference but was unable to apply them.
    14. I did a good job of communicating my thinking.
    15. I have had my notebook checked by my geometry teacher.
    16. I have shown my test to my parents and discussed it with them.
    17. My test grade accurately reflects the current state of my knowledge of geometry.

For each of the numbered triangles in Isometries I, label the vertices D′, C′, and B′ so that
ΔDBC ≅ ΔD′C′B′, and precisely specify the transformation(s) from ΔDBC to ΔD′C′B′:
  • For a reflection (flip), give the axis or equation of the line over which it is reflected.
  • For a translation (slide), give the direction(s) and number of units in which it is translated.
  • For a rotation (spin), give the center and number of degrees through which it is rotated.
Sometime two or more transformations are required (in the correct sequence).

Data Structures


Read chapter 9 on lists and then do the following:
  1. 9.1.2

  2. 9.1.4

  3. 9.3.1

  4. 9.3.3

  5. Make a template for processing a list of numbers.

  6. Use the template to define a function that consumes a list of numbers and returns the sum of the numbers in the list.

  7. Use the template to define a function that consumes a list of numbers and returns whether or not a given number is in the list.

  8. Challenging: Use the template to define a function that increments each number on the list by a given amount and returns the updated list.

  9. More Challenging: Use the template to define a function that consumes a non-empty list of numbers and returns the largest number. (Hint: think about how the recursion should end, it's not the empty list.)

Practice for the test. This is best done by redoing problems from previous homework and quizzes, as well as the previous test. You may use one side of a 3"-by-5" notecard that you have prepared in your own handwriting. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning calculator. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. You will not be given extra time unless you have a legal right to it because of an IEP or a 504; in those cases you must still begin and end the test on the same day. You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:
  1. Simplify algebraic expressions, including the correct use of combining like terms, the distributive property, and squaring.
  2. Translate expressions and functions from NetLogo to algebraic notation and vice versa.
  3. Given one representation (algebraic rule or formula, table, graph, function machines), represent a function in the other three.
  4. Find values of simple and composite functions for various inputs.
  5. From the graphing form of a quadratic function, identify the directions in which the parent parabola y=x2 has been moved or stretched, and by how much.
  6. Do the same for the graph of a function that is new to you.
  7. Distinguish linear from quadratic and other functions by their graphs (lines vs. parabolas vs. other), their tables (constant vs. second-difference growth), and their algebraic rules (presence or absence of x2 or higher term).
  8. Identify the domain and range of a function.
  9. Find the inverse of a function by backtracking and by graphing.
  10. Solve quadratic equations by backtracking, factoring, and the Quadratic Formula.
  11. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

Study for the test. This is best done by redoing problems from previous homework and quizzes, as well as the previous test. You may use one side of a 3"-by-5" notecard that you have prepared in your own handwriting. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning calculator. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. You will not be given extra time unless you have a legal right to it because of an IEP or a 504; in those cases you must still begin and end the test on the same day. You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:

1. Simplify algebraic expressions, including the correct use of combining like terms, the distributive property, and squaring.

2. Translate expressions and functions from NetLogo to algebraic notation and vice versa.

3. Given one representation (algebraic rule or formula, table, graph, function machines, NetLogo), represent a function in the other three.

4. Find values of simple and composite functions for various inputs.

5. From the graphing form of a quadratic function, identify the directions in which the parent parabola y=x2 has been moved or stretched, and by how much.

6. Do the same for the graph of a function that is new to you.

7. Distinguish linear from quadratic and other functions by their graphs (lines vs. parabolas vs. other), their tables (constant vs. second-difference growth), and their algebraic rules (presence or absence of x2 or higher term).

8. Identify the domain and range of a function.

9. Find the inverse of a function by backtracking and by graphing.

10. Convert between forms of quadratic functions (standard, vertex, factored).

11. Solve quadratic equations by backtracking, completing the square/backtracking, zero product property, factoring/zero product property, and the Quadratic Formula.

12. Identify or find the vertex, x-intercepts, and y-intercept given any form of a quadratic function.

13. Be able to identify the number of solutions given any function.

14. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

1. Complete Exponential Growth worksheet, which you started in class.

  2. Read the bottom half of p. 247 of the textbook for a quick summary of the distinction between an exponential function (where the variable x is an exponent), and a power function (where the variable x is the base). For example, y = 2x and y = 3x are two familiar exponential functions, but y = x2 and y = x3 are power functions.

  3. Lesson 5.1, p. 242, #8(a and b only), 9(a and b only). Lesson 5.2, p. 249, #9, 10(a and b only), 14.

Finish reading Plato’s “Allegory of the Cave.” (You may want to start over again from the beginning, even though we read more than half of it aloud in class.) Then write or type answers to the following questions:
  1. Some readers think that the people in Plato’s cave are seeing shadows of real objects. For instance, they see a shadow of a dog, though they imagine that they are seeing a real dog. But it’s actually even more indirect than that. Explain what the people are really seeing. (Hint: Read section 515a again.)

  2. When we draw a square, to what extent is it really a square? Be specific!

  3. Suppose we constructed the square. How does that change your answer to the previous question?

  4. How real is the number –3? How about 1/3? How about 3? Is one of these more real than the others?

  5. Who is the person who “sees the light” in the dialog? If necessary, read section 516 again.

  6. Explain Socrates’ remark in 518c : “Education is not what the professions of certain men assert it to be. They presumably assert that they put into the soul knowledge that isn’t in it, as though they were putting sight into blind eyes.”

  7. Draw a picture of what Plato is describing. Label anything in the picture that won’t be clear to your audience. It doesn’t have to be a work of art, but it does need to show accurately what Plato is describing. Be prepared to share your picture with the class.

Also, here are a few more hints for the challenging problem from the previous assignment:
  • If you aren’t using all four of the givens, you’re doing something wrong.
  • If you haven’t constructed at least two more lines (or line segments), you’re probably doing something wrong. Use the points where the arc you drew intersects the sides of the big isosceles triangle (or their extensions).
  • If you haven’t found a pair of congruent triangles, you’re probably doing something wrong.

These questions concern the version of Newton’s method that was shown in class:
  1. In finding the square root of a positive number, what happens when the seed is negative? Can you prove that this conclusion is always correct?

  2. Adapt the algorithm so that you are finding the cube root of a number. Try out your version by finding the cube roots of 8, 9, and –8, using several seeds, both positive and negative. Do you always find the real cube root? Or do you sometimes find a non-real complex root? Does it depend on the seed?

Through experimentation, come up with a good conjecture for this question: Which of the two square roots and which of the three cube roots are found by Newton’s method when applied to a complex number? To be able to compare consistently, try the two square roots of –5–12i (which are 2–3i and –2+3i) and the three cube roots of 8 (which we worked on in class). Keep in mind the original conjecture that it depended on the quadrant of the seed. This turned out not to be quite correct — but it was correct enough in lots of cases that we want to modify it rather than throwing it out altogether.

1. Be sure that the following definitions are in your notebook:
    When iterating any particular function...
    • The Filled-in Julia Set or (preferably) Filled Julia Set (FJS) for that function is the set of all prisoners.
    • The Julia Set for that function is the set of points on the edge or border of the FJS. These are a subset of the prisoners, namely those that can become escapees with the slightest change; their orbit is chaotic.
  2. Complete Exploring Julia Sets I (begun in class)..

You will be well prepared if you can do all of the following:
  1. Solve systems of linear and/or non-linear equations by graphing.
  2. Solve systems of linear and/or non-linear equations by substitution.
  3. Solve systems of linear equations by elimination.
  4. Write a system of equations from a word problem or story problem and solve it in the prescribed way in order to show your work.
  5. Recognize and create situations where there are no solutions or infinite solutions.
  6. Explain all of the above clearly and accurately.

Write a detailed progress report for your project. You should include the following:
  • a description of what you have done so far
  • a description of just what you still have left to do
  • a full list of all your sources,
  • an explanation of just what contribution each group member is making and is going to make (be sure to name names).

An ancient Chinese problem asks for the least number of gold coins a band of 17 pirates could have stolen. When the pirates divided the coins into equal piles, 3 were left over. When they fought over the extra 3 coins, one of the pirates was slain. When the remaining pirates divided the coins into equal piles, 10 coins were left over. They fought again, and another was slain. Now when they divided the coins none were left over. How many coins did they have?

1. Read How Bits and Bytes Works (through the Binary math section).

  2. Read The Binary System. Answer the embedded questions before checking your answers (no need to submit the answers).

  3. Answer the following questions and email the answers to me.

    1. Many people referred to the year 2000 as Y2K, or Year 2K. That’s on the theory that K stands for 1000, which it doesn’t. What year will really be Y2K?
    2. Investigate the y2k38 problem. Do you think this will be a real problem? Why?
    3. Convert the binary numeral 11100101 to decimal.
    4. Convert the decimal numeral 107 to binary.
    5. What is the easiest way to multiply by 4 in binary?
    6. Add 10100011 to 11000010 in binary without converting to decimal and back again.
    7. In the previous question, your answer should have been more than 8 bits long. If your computer couldn’t handle numbers larger than 8 bits, only the rightmost 8 bits would be kept. What would your answer to the previous question be in this case? Figure out how far off it would be by subtracting the computed result from the true result and converting to decimal.
    8. Convert -7 to two's complement form
    9. Use two's complement form to subtract 7 from 12

Complete The Logistic Map, at least through #13. You will need to know the definitions of attracting and repelling fixed points before doing this. There are good definitions at www.jcu.edu/math/Vignettes/orbits.htm:
A fixed point may be an attracting fixed point, meaning that the orbits of nearby points converge — are attracted to — the fixed point; or it may be a repelling fixed point, meaning that the orbits of nearby points move away from the fixed point. Other fixed points may be neither attracting nor repelling. For f(x) = x2, 0 is an attracting fixed point while 1 is a repelling fixed point. (Calculate the orbits of x = .999 and x = 1.001 to convince yourself.)

1. Read and study Sections 10.2 and 10.3, but definitely do not learn all eight theorems in these sections! The key to condensing the eight theorems into two is to recall what “⇔” means: “A ⇔ B” is shorthand for “If A then B, and if B then A.” The authors have used this symbol in the middle of p. 453, where they condense Theorems 79–84 into a single sentence.
  2. Explain why we could legitimately condense their sentence even further by eliminating the words “the same circle or in.”
  3. Use a similar technique to read Theorems 77 and 78 on p. 446 and condense them into a single sentence.
  4. On p. 449, do problems #10, 12, 14.
  5. On p. 457, do problems #19, 20, 22.

We’re now going to move partially away from the textbook for a few days, replacing the next 19 definitions, 2 postulates, and 13 theorems with a very small number of each: approximately 5 definitions, 0 postulates, and 3 theorems! During the test you may use one side of a 3"-by-5" notecard that you have prepared in your own handwriting. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning calculator. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. You will be well prepared if you can do all of the following:

  1. Encipher and decipher with substitution ciphers.
  2. Encipher and decipher with Caesar ciphers.
  3. Encipher and decipher with affine ciphers in various mods, including identification of good and bad ciphers.
  4. Apply the concept of congruence classes.
  5. Apply modular arithmetic in three contexts:
    • finding reciprocals in various mods
    • using mod as a binary operation [such as 28 mod 5]
    • solving congruences [such as 3x +5 ≡ 12 (mod 4)].
  6. Advise Alice and Bob on the advantages and disadvantages of the cryptosystems (other than RSA) discussed in the Big Question.
  7. Explain all of the above clearly and accurately.

TEST REVIEW: On Wednesday from 2:55 to 3:35 there will be an optional review session for Friday's test (in Room 200).

Practice for the test. Be sure to look over all handouts, notes, quizzes, and homework. You need to know all the geometry in Assignments #1–80, including the material in Chapters One–Twelve (through Section 12.3) of the textbook, especially the information on area, dissection, basic right-triangle trigonometry, angles in or near circles, circular segments and sectors, arc lengths and measures, tangents to circles, lengths of line segments in or near circles (Power of the Point), similarity, triangles and other polygons, the Pythagorean Theorem, and Special Right Triangles (30°-60°-90° and 45°-45°-90°). The emphasis will be on areas and circles. There are very few formulas that you have to learn: area of a trapezoid, surface area of a sphere, and surface area of a cone are about the only ones! All the others can (and should) be avoided just by thinking about the problem (assuming, of course, that you know the area of a circle and you know how to dissect flat figures and cylinders).

The final exam will begin promptly at 7:50 AM in Room 8 for students with extra time, or at 8:50 AM in Room 14 for those with regular time. In either case it ends at 10:50 AM. On the exam you will be allowed to use two 3"-by-5" notecards written in your own handwriting. We recommend one unit per notecard side, since we’ve studied four units:
  • Quadratics
  • Exponents & Logs
  • Systems of Equations & Inequalities
  • Crypto & Number Theory
Check out the cover sheet ahead of time so that the format will produce no surprises when you walk into the exam.

You will be well-prepared for the exam if you can do the following:
  1. Identify whether a function is linear, exponential, or quadratic, given an English description, a table, or an equation.

  2. Represent a linear, exponential, or quadratic function as a description, a table, and a graph, given any one of these.

  3. Simplify algebraic expressions, including the correct use of combining like terms, the distributive property, and squaring.

  4. Convert quadratic functions from factored form or vertex (graphing) form to general (standard) form.

  5. Complete the square in order to convert a quadratic function from standard form to graphing form.

  6. Given one representation (algebraic rule or formula, table, graph, function machines), represent a quadratic function in the other three.

  7. From the graphing form of a quadratic function, identify the directions in which the prototype parabola y = x2 has been moved, and by how much.

  8. Distinguish linear, exponential, and quadratic functions by their graphs, their algebraic rules, and their tables.

  9. Distinguish exponential from power functions.

  10. Given two points (either on a graph or in a table), construct a linear and/or an exponential function passing through those points.

  11. Given an input and a function, find the output for that input.

  12. Recognize characteristic graphs of exponential and quadratic functions.

  13. Convert equations from exponential to logarithmic form and vice versa.

  14. Evaluate logarithms to any given base, using your calculator where necessary.

  15. Interpret logarithmic functions as the inverses of the corresponding exponential functions.

  16. Use logarithms to solve exponential equations and roots (or fractional exponents) to solve power equations.

  17. Use the properties of exponents to simplify expressions.

  18. Apply exponents and logarithms by constructing and using exponential models to describe read-world situations.

  19. Solve a linear equation in one variable.

  20. Graph a linear or exponential equation in two variables.

  21. Solve word problems involving systems of equations by the method of your choice.

  22. Solve a system of equations in two variables by graphing, and determine whether the equations are independent, dependent, or inconsistent.

  23. Solve a system of equations in two variables by substitution, elimination, or matrices.

  24. Find sum, difference, product, and inverse of matrices. Identify when those are nonexistent or undefined (and explain why).

  25. Solve equations in which the solutions represent matrices or variables within matrices.

  26. Graph linear inequalities.

  27. Graph systems of linear inequalities, and use the results to solve and interpret linear programming problems.

  28. Use the mod operation correctly.

  29. Encipher and decipher with Caesar, substitution, affine, matrix, and RSA ciphers. (You will not need to do the exact RSA calculations as part of the exam — you already did them outside of class in RSA Part Four — but you do need to be able to follow the steps in the process.)

  30. Determine and apply congruence classes for various moduli.

  31. Determine good and bad affine and matrix ciphers.

  32. Understand what reciprocals (multiplicative inverses) are, and apply them to the solution of congruences.

  33. Show your work and explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

You need to know all the geometry in Assignments #1–86, including the reading in the link in Assignment #85 and of course the material we covered in Chapters One–Twelve of the textbook, especially the information on lateral area, total surface area, volumes, and Platonic Solids. The exam will include numerical problems (2-D, 3-D) and proofs (2-D only) on the following topics:
  1. Angles, lines, line segments, & planes (complements/supplements, parallels, perpendiculars, midpoints, etc.)
  2. Congruent triangles (SAS, SSS, ASA, AAS, HL, CPCTC)
  3. Triangle properties (medians, altitudes, concurrencies at various “centers”, Angle Bisector Theorem)
  4. Equidistance Theorems and Midline Theorem
  5. Quadrilaterals (including the hierarchy)
  6. Polygons and polyhedra (including isosceles triangles, angles & diagonals in regular polygons, and Platonic solids)
  7. Similar figures and proportions (including similar right triangles)
  8. Pythagorean Theorem & special right triangles
  9. Right-triangle trigonometry
  10. Equations of lines, midpoints, slopes, intersections, distance
  11. Circles (radii, chords, arcs, angles, tangents, power of the point, sectors, circular segments)
  12. Area, perimeter, and volume (including surface area and scale factors)

You will be well-prepared for the exam if you can do the following:

      1. Identify whether a function is linear, exponential, or quadratic, given an English description, a table, or an equation.
      2. Represent a linear, exponential, or quadratic function as a description, a table, and a graph, given any one of these.
      3. Simplify algebraic expressions, including the correct use of combining like terms, the distributive property, and squaring.
      4. Convert quadratic functions from factored form or vertex (graphing) form to general (standard) form.
      5. Complete the square in order to convert a quadratic function from standard form to graphing form.
      6. Given one representation (algebraic rule or formula, table, graph, function machines), represent a quadratic function in the other three.
      7. From the graphing form of a quadratic function, identify the directions in which the prototype parabola y = x2 has been moved, and by how much.
      8. Distinguish linear, exponential, and quadratic functions by their graphs, their algebraic rules, and their tables.
      9. Distinguish exponential from power functions.
      10. Given two points (either on a graph or in a table), construct a linear and/or an exponential function passing through those points.
      11. Given an input and a function, find the output for that input.
      12. Recognize characteristic graphs of exponential and quadratic functions.
      13. Convert equations from exponential to logarithmic form and vice versa.
      14. Evaluate logarithms to any given base, using your calculator where necessary.
      15. Interpret logarithmic functions as the inverses of the corresponding exponential functions.
      16. Use logarithms to solve exponential equations and roots (or fractional exponents) to solve power equations.
      17. Use the properties of exponents to simplify expressions.
      18. Apply exponents and logarithms by constructing and using exponential models to describe read-world situations.
      19. Solve a linear equation in one variable.
      20. Graph a linear or exponential equation in two variables.
      21. Solve word problems involving systems of equations by the method of your choice.
      22. Solve a system of equations in two variables by graphing, and determine whether the equations are independent, dependent, or inconsistent.
      23. Solve a system of equations in two variables by substitution, elimination, or matrices.
      24. Find sum, difference, product, and inverse of matrices. Identify when those are nonexistent or undefined (and explain why).
      25. Solve equations in which the solutions represent matrices or variables within matrices.
      26. Graph linear inequalities.
      27. Graph systems of linear inequalities, and use the results to solve and interpret linear programming problems.
      28. Use the mod operation correctly.
      29. Encipher and decipher with Caesar, substitution, affine, matrix, and RSA ciphers.
      30. Determine and apply congruence classes for various moduli.
      31. Determine good and bad affine and matrix ciphers.
      32. Understand what reciprocals (multiplicative inverses) are, and apply them to the solution of congruences.
      33. Show your work and explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

Data Types


Read chapter 2 and chapter 3 in the online textbook.

In this — and all subsequent function definitions — you must include a contract, a purpose statement, and at least one test case.

Download Data-Type.py and complete the following excercises:
  • Utopia's tax accountants always use programs that compute income taxes even though the tax rate is a solid, never-changing 15%. Define the functions gross_pay, tax, and net_pay.
    Assume an hourly rate of $12.
    Note:
    "gross pay" is what you earn before taxes.
    "net pay" is what you take home after taxes are deducted.
  • The local supermarket needs a program that can compute the value of a bag of coins. Define the function sum-coins. It consumes four numbers: the number of pennies, nickels, dimes, and quarters in the bag; it produces the amount of money in the bag.
  • An old-style movie theater has a simple profit function. Each customer pays $5 per ticket. Every performance costs the theater $20, plus $.50 per attendee. Develop the function total-profit. It consumes the number of attendees (of a show) and produces how much income the attendees produce. Solution

• If necessary, re-read the document that we read aloud in class: Tests & Quizzes.
  • Complete Sine, Cosine, Tangent: Ratios or Functions?
Read chapter 3 in the book, paying close attention to when they decide to use which type of picture. Also, make up an example that demonstrates Simpson's Paradox, similar to the one shown on page 33.

Branching

Read chapter 4.1 - 4.8, 4.10, and 4.12 in the online textbook.

Download Branching.py and complete the following exercises:
  1. Develop a function called can_vote that consumes a person’s age and produces a boolean that tells you whether the person is old enough to vote.

  2. Write a program that consumes a number representing a student’s percentage score on a test and produces a string representing an appropriate comment for that student. For example, teacher_comment(72) might produce "should try harder".

  3. Use symbols for the days of the week.
    Write a function is_weekday that consumes a day of the week symbol and produces a boolean that tells you whether or not the day is a weekday.

  4. Write a program begins_with_vowel that consumes a string and produces a boolean that tells you whether or not the word begins with a vowel.

In class, we received solutions for the Sine, Cosine, Tangent sheet and reviewed any lingering questions. Next, we did a brief recap of important review-type items that have come up in class so far; rationalizing denominators (both root and conjugate), SOHCAHTOA and its associated domain, 30-60-90 and 45-45-90 triangles, root of product/quotient rules, and the composition of functions. After that, we talked about the idea of expanding domains and how in math, there is a recurring idea that often when you first learn a new function, you initially work in a relatively restricted domain. As you understanding of that functions expands, you often expand the domain; this is what we've been doing with Trig functions. We then did the first problem from the Morphing Right Triangles sheet, reviewed a little bit about Sketchpad, then headed off to the lab. In that lab, we worked on problems 2 and 3 - most people did not get to number 4. HW - nothing new; see me for extra help/support if you've been struggling.

Iteration and Strings


Read chapter 6 and chapter 7 in the online textbook.

Download Iteration-Strings.py and complete the following exercises:
  1. Write a program called pig that translates a word (in the form of a string) into Pig Latin. Use the simplest dialect of Pig Latin, in which you move an initial consonant (if any) to the end and add "ay" (so "string" becomes "tringsay" and "easy" becomes "easyay"). You may want to use the begins_with_vowel program that we developed in class.

  2. Write a program called pigg that translates a word (in the form of a string) into Pig Latin. Use the dialect of Pig Latin in which you add "way" to a word that begins with a vowel (so "easy" becomes "easyway"), otherwise you move any initial consonants to the end and add "ay" (so "string" becomes "ingstray").

  3. Challenging: Write a function piggy that correctly handles the cases where y is a vowel as in the word myth . It must also handle the case where y is a consonant as in the word year.

  4. Very Challenging: correctly handle words with no vowels such as tsk or cwm.

Data Structures - Lists


Read chapter 9.1 - 9.16 in the online textbook.
Read the Google Python List Reference and then do the following:
  1. Develop the function contains_doll, which consumes a list of strings and determines whether one of them is "doll".
    Create enough test cases to completely test your code.

  2. Develop the function contains_string, which consumes a string and a list of strings and determines whether or not the string occurs in the list.

  3. Hopefully you used the "in" operator supplied by Python when doing the previous exercises. Now implement your own version of "in" by looping through all the strings on a list looking for a given string.

  4. Define a function that consumes a list of numbers and returns the sum of the numbers in the list.

  5. Define a function that consumes a list of numbers and returns whether or not a given number is in the list.

  6. Challenging: Define a function that increments each number on the list by a given amount and returns the updated list.

  7. More Challenging: Define a function that consumes a non-empty list of numbers and returns the largest number.

  8. Even More Challenging: Write an "in" function that is data-type independent.

Recursion


Read chapter 11.6 - 11.8 in the online textbook and then do the following:
  1. Write a recursive function that consumes a number(n) and produces n factorial.

  2. Write a recursive function that consumes a number(n) and produces a list of the first n Fibonacci numbers.

  3. Challenge: Have your code raise an appropriate exception if it receives a bad user input value.

    4. If your functions have "ugly" interfaces then write "wrapper" functions that provide a clean interface to the user.

In class, and on the last assignment, you analyzed a set of wrapping functions for a square path.

Now sketch graphs for a diamond-shape path, where the guards walk straight from each of the following points to the next, eventually returning to the starting point and wrapping around the diamond again and again: (3, 0); (0, 4); (–3, 0); (0, –4). In this case the function that produces the x-coordinate is called diamx, the one that produces the y-coordinate is called diamy, and the one that produces the rotation angle with its vertex at the origin is called diamang.

Finally, sketch three similar graphs for a circular path, where the guards walk around a circle centered at the origin, starting at (1, 0). In this case the function that produces the x-coordinate is called xc, the one that produces the y-coordinate is called ys, and the one that produces the rotation angle with its vertex at the origin is called rad.

The following procedure always leads to the same number, called Kaprekar’s Constant. Try it for at least two numbers.
1. Take any four-digit number, using at least two different digits. (Leading zeros are allowed.) 2. Arrange the digits in ascending (smallest to largest) and then in descending (largest to smallest) order to get two four-digit numbers, adding leading zeros if necessary. 3. Subtract the smaller number from the bigger number. 4. Go back to step 2, and continue this process until you see a repeating pattern...
Is there a similar constant for 3-digit numbers? If so, find it! How about 5-digit numbers?

As preparation for the test, I strongly suggest that you do these practice problems. Answers will be posted on Wednesday.

You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:
  1. Simplify algebraic expressions, including the correct use of combining like terms, the distributive property, and squaring.
  2. Given one representation (algebraic rule or formula, table, graph, function machines, geometric description, computer program), represent a function in the others.
  3. Find values of simple and composite functions for various inputs.
  4. From the graphing form of a quadratic function, identify the directions in which the parent parabola y=x2 has been moved, and by how much.
  5. Do the same for the graph of a function that is new to you.
  6. Distinguish linear from quadratic and other functions by their graphs (lines vs. parabolas vs. other), their tables (constant vs. second-difference growth), and their algebraic rules (presence or absence of x2 or higher term).
  7. Tell whether a relation is a function or not.
  8. Identify the domain and range of a function.
  9. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:
     1. Simplify algebraic expressions, including the correct use of combining like terms, the distributive property, and squaring.
     2. Given one representation (algebraic rule or formula, table, graph, function machines, geometric description, computer program), represent a function in the others.
     3. Find values of simple and composite functions for various inputs.
     4. From the graphing form of a quadratic function, identify the directions in which the parent parabola y=x^2 has been moved, and by how much.
     5. Do the same for the graph of a function that is new to you.
     6. Distinguish linear from quadratic and other functions by their graphs (lines vs. parabolas vs. other), their tables (constant vs. second-difference growth), and their algebraic rules (presence or absence of x^2 or higher term).
     7. Tell whether a relation is a function or not.
     8. Identify the domain and range of a function.
     9. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

  • Consider ΔOAK with these vertices:
    O(0, 0)
    A(24, 0)
    K(16, 14)
    Let the midpoint of side OA be H. (Why H?)
    Let the midpoint of side OK be M. (Why M?)
    Let the midpoint of side AK be F. (Why F?)
    Calculate the coordinates of H, M, and F. Then find the equations of two of the medians of ΔOAK. Finally, find the coordinates of the centroid of ΔOAK.

  • Prove that the incenter of a triangle is the intersection of the angle bisectors. (To do this, you will need to know that radii of the inscribed circle ending at the sides of the triangle are perpendicular to those sides.)

  • Draw a large random scalene triangle with a lot of blank space around it, and construct the incenter of the triangle.

  • Redraw points O, A, K, H, M, and F from the preceding assignment. Then find the equations of two of the altitudes of ΔOAK. Finally, find the coordinates of the orthocenter of ΔOAK.

• Redraw points O, A, K, H, M, and F from the preceding assignment. Then find the equations of the perpendicular bisectors of two of the sides of ΔOAK. Finally, find the coordinates of the circumcenter of ΔOAK.

Study for the test. This is best done by redoing problems from previous homework and quizzes, as well as the previous test. You may use one side of a 3"-by-5" notecard that you have prepared in your own handwriting. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning calculator. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. You will not be given extra time unless you have a legal right to it because of an IEP or a 504; in those cases you must still begin and end the test on the same day. You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:

     1. Simplify algebraic expressions, including the correct use of combining like terms, the distributive property, and squaring.
     2. Translate expressions and functions from NetLogo to algebraic notation and vice versa.
     3. Given one representation (algebraic rule or formula, table, graph, function machines, NetLogo), represent a function in the other three.
     4. Find values of simple and composite functions for various inputs.
     5. From the graphing form of a quadratic function, identify the directions in which the parent parabola y=x2 has been moved or stretched, and by how much.
     6. Do the same for the graph of a function that is new to you.
     7. Distinguish linear from quadratic and other functions by their graphs, their tables, and their algebraic rules.
     8. Identify the domain and range of a function.
     9. Find the inverse of a function by backtracking and by graphing.
     10. Convert between forms of quadratic functions (standard, vertex, factored).
     11. Solve quadratic equations by backtracking, completing the square/backtracking, zero product property, factoring/zero product property, and Quadratic Formula.
     12. Identify or find the vertex, x-intercepts, and y-intercept given any form of a quadratic function.
     13. Be able to identify the number of solutions given any function.
     14. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

Practice for the test (which has been postponed to 11/7 because of unforeseen events). This is best done by redoing problems from previous homework and quizzes, as well as the previous test. You may use one side of a 3"-by-5" notecard that you have prepared in your own handwriting. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning calculator. You should also have some other work to do in case you finish before the end of the period. You will not be given extra time unless you have a legal right to it because of an IEP or a 504, in which case you must arrange for the extra time in advance and must begin and end the test on the same day. You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:
  1. Simplify algebraic expressions, including the correct use of combining like terms, the distributive property, and squaring.
  2. Translate expressions and functions from NetLogo to algebraic notation and vice versa.
  3. Given one representation (algebraic rule or formula, table, graph, function machines), represent a function in the other three.
  4. Find values of simple and composite functions for various inputs.
  5. From the graphing form of a quadratic function, identify the directions in which the parent parabola y=x2 has been moved and by how much.
  6. Do the same for the graph of a function that is new to you.
  7. Distinguish linear from quadratic and other functions by their graphs (lines vs. parabolas vs. other), their tables (constant vs. second-difference growth), and their algebraic rules (presence or absence of x2 or higher term).
  8. Identify the domain and range of a function.
  9. Find the inverse of a function by backtracking and by graphing.
  10. Complete the square.
  11. Convert a quadratic from one form to another (graphing, standard, factored).
  12. Find the x- and y-intercepts of a quadratic function.
  13. Solve quadratic equations by backtracking and/or factoring.
  14. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

You may use one side of a 3"-by-5" notecard that you have prepared in your own handwriting. Be sure that you have pencils and a functioning calculator. You will not be given extra time unless you have a legal right to it because of an IEP or a 504; in those cases you must begin and end the test on the same day, and you must arrange for your extended time beforehand.

You will be well-prepared for the test if you can do the following:
  1. Graph exponential functions and create them from their graphs and/or tables.
  2. Find the output for a given input.
  3. Find the growth factor, initial value, and equation for given data.
  4. Use the quadratic formula to solve equations.
  5. Find an input for a given output (by table or guess-and-check).
  6. Perform linear, quadratic, and exponential regression, and use r 2 to determine which is best.
  7. Use growth/decay rate vs. growth/decay factor.
  8. Calculate interest.
  9. Compare tables and graphs of functions (linear, quadratic, exponential).
  10. Apply the properties of exponents.
  11. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly.

Test #3 is today!

You are allowed one 3"x5" notecard written on one side. You will be prepared if you can do the following:

1. Graph exponential functions and create them from their graphs and/or tables.
2. Find the output for a given input.
3. Find an input for a given output (by table or guess-and-check).
4. Perform linear, quadratic, and exponential regression, and use r^2 to determine which is best.
5. Use growth/decay rate vs. growth/decay factor.
6. Calculate compound interest.
7. Compare tables and graphs of functions (linear, quadratic, exponential).
8. Translate exponential graphs.
9. Apply the properties of exponents.
10. Explain all of the above clearly and correctly.
